name: B1 — Business Visitor
summary: Short-term business travel for meetings, conferences, and negotiations.

atAGlance.eligibility: For business meetings, conferences, contract negotiations without local employment.
atAGlance.processing: Interview wait + 2–3 weeks for document review
atAGlance.validity: Usually up to 10 years for Brazilian nationals

eligibility: Intend to stay temporarily for legitimate business activities.
Maintain a residence outside the U.S. and strong ties proving return.
Have sufficient funds to cover expenses without U.S. income.

interview: Valid passport with at least 6 months beyond stay.
DS-160 confirmation page and appointment letter.
Proof of employment, role, and salary.
Invitation letter or conference registration.
Evidence of strong ties (bank statements, property, family).
forms: Optional: company support letter summarizing travel purpose.

timelines.notes: Includes MRV wait, interview availability, and passport return. Peak seasons may exceed 6 months.

steps: Create profile on ustraveldocs and complete DS-160.
Pay MRV fee and keep receipt number.
Schedule CASV biometrics and embassy/consulate interview.
Attend biometrics appointment for fingerprints and photo.
Participate in visa interview with supporting evidence.
Track passport return via courier or pick-up instructions.
interviewTips: Answer clearly and concisely about the business agenda.
Show proof of continuing employment and responsibilities in home country.
Carry translations of documents not in English.
afterDenial: Review 214(b) refusal reasons and strengthen evidence of ties.
Obtain detailed invitation letters outlining meetings and sponsorship.
Reapply only when new information or stronger evidence is available.

faqs.q: Can I receive payment from a U.S. company on B1?
faqs.a: No. Compensation must come from a non-U.S. source except reimbursement for incidental expenses.
It is recommended to demonstrate purpose, but not mandatory if other proof is provided.

faqs.q: How long can I stay per visit?
faqs.a: CBP officers typically grant up to 6 months, but it may vary by case.

premium.teaser: Detailed scripts for business interviews and sample company support letters.

name: B2 — Tourist Visitor
summary: Tourism, leisure travel, or medical treatment in the United States.

atAGlance.eligibility: Visits for tourism, family events, or medical care without U.S. employment.

eligibility: Plan a temporary visit for pleasure or medical treatment.
Demonstrate ability to cover travel and medical costs.
Show ties to home country ensuring return.

interview: Passport valid for six months beyond stay.
DS-160 confirmation and appointment letter.
Travel itinerary or proof of accommodation.
Financial statements proving funds.
For medical travel: letter from U.S. physician and payment arrangements.

timelines.notes: Appointment availability can extend beyond 8 months in high-demand posts.

steps: Submit DS-160 and upload compliant photo.
Pay MRV and schedule CASV + interview.
Attend biometrics appointment.
Prepare supporting evidence (ties, travel plan, finances).
Attend interview and respond honestly.
Wait for passport delivery with visa foil.
interviewTips: Explain clearly who is paying for the trip and why.
Bring proof of previous travel if any.
If medical, show treatment plan and financial guarantees.
afterDenial: Identify missing ties such as employment or property.
Gather documentation of social, financial, and family commitments.
Consider reapplying after significant changes (new job, assets).

faqs.a: Not required but strongly recommended, especially for medical travel.

faqs.q: Can I study short courses on B2?
faqs.a: Short recreational courses are allowed; full-time study requires F1/J1.

faqs.q: Can family accompany me to medical treatment?
faqs.a: Yes, relatives can apply for B2 visas as caregivers with supporting documents.

name: F1 — Academic Student
summary: Full-time academic or language studies at accredited U.S. institutions.

atAGlance.eligibility: Must have I-20 from SEVP-certified school and show funding for first year.

eligibility: Receive acceptance and Form I-20 from SEVP-certified institution.
Demonstrate sufficient funds for tuition and living expenses.
Show intent to return home after studies.
Maintain academic preparation matching program level.

interview: Passport and DS-160 confirmation.
SEVIS payment receipt (I-901).
Original I-20 signed by applicant and school.
Academic transcripts and standardized test scores.
Financial proof: bank statements, sponsor letters, scholarships.

timelines.notes: Plan early to align with program start. Administrative processing may extend timeline.

steps: Obtain I-20 and pay SEVIS fee.
Complete DS-160 and schedule appointments.
Gather financial and academic documentation.
Attend biometrics and visa interview.
Receive passport and review visa annotations.
Enter U.S. up to 30 days before program start.
interviewTips: Explain program choice and career goals succinctly.
Show ties that ensure return after studies (family, career path).
Be ready to discuss funding sources in detail.
afterDenial: Address funding shortfalls with clearer documentation.
Provide stronger evidence of academic preparedness or new acceptance letters.
Reapply with updated SEVIS fee receipt if needed.

faqs.a: Yes, up to 20 hours per week during term once studies begin.
Yes, spouse and children require F2 visas with proof of relationship and funds.

faqs.q: When can I apply for OPT?
faqs.a: Eligible students may apply for Optional Practical Training after completing one academic year.

name: J1 — Exchange Visitor
summary: Cultural and educational exchange programs including trainees, researchers, and au pairs.

atAGlance.eligibility: Requires DS-2019 from program sponsor and proof of sufficient funds.
atAGlance.entries: Single or multiple depending on sponsor

eligibility: Accepted into a designated exchange visitor program.
Meet specific category requirements (trainee, scholar, au pair).
Show funding and health insurance meeting U.S. regulations.
Intend to return home after program per 212(e) home residency rules if applicable.

interview: Passport, DS-160, and DS-2019 signed by sponsor.
Proof of SEVIS payment if required.
Evidence of financial support (stipends, savings, sponsor letter).
Program-specific documents (training plan DS-7002, offer letters).
Proof of medical insurance coverage meeting minimum requirements.

timelines.notes: Timeframe depends on sponsor document issuance and embassy availability.

steps: Secure program sponsorship and receive DS-2019.
Pay SEVIS fee if required and complete DS-160.
Schedule CASV and embassy interview appointments.
Prepare program documents and insurance proof.
Attend biometrics and visa interview.
Collect passport and review visa annotations including 212(e) notice.
interviewTips: Describe how the exchange fits long-term goals in home country.
Carry sponsor contact and emergency information.
Highlight cultural exchange components, not just work duties.
afterDenial: Review whether funding or program clarity was insufficient.
Coordinate with sponsor to address concerns or issue updated documents.
Consider alternative program dates if appointment timing caused delays.

faqs.q: What is the two-year home residency requirement?
faqs.a: Certain J1 categories must return home for two years before applying for H/L immigrant visas or status changes unless they obtain a waiver.

faqs.q: Can I change employers on J1 trainee?
faqs.a: Only with sponsor approval and updated DS-2019/DS-7002 documentation.

faqs.q: Do J2 dependents need separate SEVIS fees?
faqs.a: No, but they must obtain J2 visas and carry proof of funds and relationship.
